advisors.name: Angela Nguyen
advisors.bio: Angela Nguyen has served the Houston community for over 25 years as a financial advisor. Her expertise in tax planning and risk management have proven invaluable to her clients, helping them navigate complex financial landscapes with ease and confidence.

advisors.name: Marcus Johnson
advisors.bio: Marcus Johnson, with his 30 years of experience in the financial industry, has established himself as a leading advisor in Houston. His exceptional skills in wealth management and crafting tailored investment strategies have consistently met and exceeded his clients' expectations.

advisors.name: Isabella Martinez

advisors.name: David Kim

heroDescription: Finding a financial advisor in Houston can be a strategic move to navigate the city's diverse economy and high cost of living.
landscapeDescription: According to the Bureau of Economic Analysis (2020), Houston's economy is robust, with a GDP of $490 billion. Major employers include the Texas Medical Center, NASA's Johnson Space Center, and several Fortune 500 companies.
uniqueNeeds: Given Houston's high cost of living and diverse economic landscape, residents may benefit from tailored financial planning.

sections.title: Economic Growth
sections.description: According to Bureau of Economic Analysis (2019), Houston's GDP was $490 billion, making it the 7th largest in the nation. The city's economy grew by 2.4% in 2019, slightly above the national average of 2.3%.

sections.title: Wealth Demographics
sections.description: According to U.S. Census Bureau (2019), the median household income in Houston is $51,203. The city's poverty rate is 20.6%, which is higher than the national average of 13.4%.

sections.title: Advisor Specializations
sections.description: Based on Bureau of Labor Statistics (2019), Houston's largest employment sectors are trade, transportation, and utilities, followed by professional and business services. Financial advisors specializing in these sectors may find ample opportunities.

sections.title: Cost of Living
sections.description: According to Bureau of Labor Statistics (2020), the Consumer Price Index for Houston is 241.6, which is slightly below the national average of 245.1. This suggests that the cost of living in Houston is slightly lower than the national average.

sections.title: Real Estate Market
sections.description: According to Zillow (2021), the median home value in Houston is $202,500. Home values have gone up 5.3% over the past year and Zillow predicts they will rise 4.4% within the next year.

sections.title: Business Environment
sections.description: According to Fortune 500 (2020), Houston is home to 41 Fortune 500 companies, second only to New York City. The city's largest company by revenue is Phillips 66, followed by Sysco and ConocoPhillips.
